/******************************************************************************
 * STM32 DAC Lookup Tables - AUTO-GENERATED CODE
 * EEE3096S Practical 4 - Tasks 1 & 2
 *
 * Total samples: 6000
 * Samples per LUT: 1000
 * DAC Resolution: 12-bit (0-4095)
 *
 * INSTRUCTIONS FOR USE:
 * 1. Copy ALL code below (from line after this comment block)
 * 2. Open your main.c file in STM32CubeIDE
 * 3. Find the section: /* USER CODE BEGIN PV */
 * 4. Paste all the code there
 * 5. Adjust F_SIGNAL based on your needs:
 *    - For musical tones (sine/sawtooth/triangle): 440 Hz
 *    - For audio playback (piano/guitar/drum): 44100 Hz
 *
 ******************************************************************************/

// These are single-cycle waveforms for tone generation

    1831, 2299,  455, 1876, 2004, 2034, 2423, 2067, 1909, 1757, 2423, 1550,
    2320, 2119, 1689, 2264, 2035, 1928, 2114, 1952, 1972, 2102, 2046, 2094,

    2111, 2019, 2081, 1982, 2087, 2043, 2767, 4090, 3052, 1590, 1859, 2122,

    2044, 2041, 2043, 2056, 2117, 1119, 2417, 2569,  701, 2916,  952, 1965,
    2580, 1105, 2993, 1719, 1960, 1941, 2436, 1661, 2496,   70,  587, 1878,
    2233, 2599, 2038, 2021, 2220, 1643, 2512, 1600, 2164, 2122, 2052, 1727,

    2063, 2051, 2036, 1956,   16,  999, 2015, 2250, 2612, 3087, 2364, 2333,
    1311, 2375, 1398, 2315, 2163, 2006, 1969, 2354, 1715, 2208, 2184, 1804,

    2070, 2236, 2730, 1782, 2064, 1841, 1781, 2522, 1887, 1952, 2231, 1929,

    2288, 1199, 2626, 1380, 2685, 2001, 1887, 2363, 2017, 1992, 2248, 1940,
    1896, 2246, 1883, 2140, 2106, 1953, 2080, 1994, 2120, 2002, 2057, 2110,
    4095, 2172,  670, 1815, 2151, 2423, 1955, 1716, 1915, 2123, 2181, 2082,
    2038, 2008, 2035, 2078, 2093, 2024, 2038, 2062, 2043, 2048, 2044, 2033,
    2044, 2064, 2031, 2050, 2036, 2068, 2091,  926, 1828, 2282, 2153, 2113,
    1971, 1901, 1991, 2035, 2063, 2052, 2047, 2036, 2052, 2044, 2643, 4095,
     730, 3650,  339, 3935, 1869, 2217, 1795, 2253, 1645, 2476, 2072, 1822,
    2089, 2168, 2047, 2047
};

// ========== TASK 2: Timing Parameters ==========

#define NS 1000  // Number of samples in each LUT
#define TIM2CLK 16000000UL  // Timer2 clock frequency in Hz (16 MHz)

// F_SIGNAL: Desired output frequency in Hz
// Valid range: 10 Hz to 2402 Hz (limited by Nyquist: TIM2CLK / (2 * NS))
// Recommended values:
//   - 440 Hz for musical tones (A4 note)
//   - 44100 Hz for audio playback (though this exceeds Nyquist limit)
#define F_SIGNAL 440  // Change this based on your waveform type

// ========== TASK 3: Timer Ticks Calculation ==========

// TIM2_TICKS determines how often the PWM duty cycle is updated
// Formula: TIM2_TICKS = TIM2CLK / (NS * F_SIGNAL)
// This value is loaded into the timer's auto-reload register
#define TIM2_TICKS (TIM2CLK / (NS * F_SIGNAL))

// Example calculations:
// For F_SIGNAL = 440 Hz:   TIM2_TICKS = 36
// For F_SIGNAL = 1000 Hz:  TIM2_TICKS = 16
// For F_SIGNAL = 44100 Hz: TIM2_TICKS = 0

// ========== Additional Notes ==========
// F_SIGNAL Limit Explanation:
// Maximum F_SIGNAL is constrained by the Nyquist theorem:
//   F_max = TIM2CLK / (2 * NS)
//   F_max = 16000000 / (2 * 1000)
//   F_max ≈ 8000 Hz
//
// Above this frequency, you cannot accurately reproduce the waveform
// because you're not updating the PWM fast enough relative to the
// output frequency.
//
// For audio playback at 44.1 kHz, you may need to:
//   1. Reduce NS (fewer samples per LUT)
//   2. Increase TIM2CLK (higher timer frequency)
//   3. Accept some aliasing/distortion
